_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Nursery, Garden Center, and Farm Supply Stores

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

1. Accidental release prevention
7 Inspect all hoses and fittings for weak spots, loose connections, worn gaskets.
7 Replace all parts, hoses, etc. that are not in good condition with approved parts.
2. Emergency response policy.
7 Remain calm
7 Assess the situation
7 Notify fire department of the existing emergency
7 Evacuate people in the downwind path of the vapor cloud movement
7 Prevent motorists from driving thru the area downwind of the emergency
7 Approach the accident from the upwind side, after putting on protective clothing and a full face gas mask with ammonia canister
7 Close the valve between the tank and the leak
3. Facility and the regulated substances handled.
7 Only anhydrous ammonia is handled at the facility.  There is one 18,000-gallon storage tank, 12 nurse tanks at the facility, filling stand, and a pump house.  It is located on the north side of the village.
4. Worse-case release scenario.
7 The worse case scenario is the release of 86,900 pounds of anhydrous ammonia into the air at a rate of 8690 pounds per minute.  The toxic endpoint would be 1.4 miles with a wind speed of 3.4 miles/hour.
5. Accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
7 We comply with the Illinois Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Products Inspection & Standards they inspect the facility yearly.
6. Five year accident history
7 The site has had no accidents is the past five years.
7. Emergency response programs
7 We are in cooperation with the Sheffield Fire Department.  They have practiced safety on the anhydrous tanks; their last practice on a tank of this size was in November 1998.
8. Planned changes to improve safety
7 We keep abreast of any necessary changes that need to be implemented through reading of various periodicals and attending required training sessions given by the Illinois Fertilizer & Chemical Association, Inc.
